placeMetadata.name: Kothari's Patwon Ki Haveli / Patwa Haveli

sources.snippet: Patwon Ki Haveli is a group of five havelis which were constructed in the first half of the 19th century and is a fine example of the Rajasthani architectonic style. This magnificent building was built by a wealthy merchant named Guman Chand Patwa and features marvellous carving work and beautiful jharokhas (a sort of enclosed balcony). The havelis are famous for the exterior designing, the doorways and the mirror work done on the walls.

Constructed at the beginning of the nineteenth century, this fancy haveli was built by rich trader Guman Chand Patwa. The huge carvings and superb craftsmanship of this beautiful building express the rich cultural heritage of the whole area.

reviews.reviewText:
A Fascinating Glimpse into Jaisalmer’s Heritage!

Kothari’s Patwon Ki Haveli is a must-visit when in Jaisalmer! This beautifully preserved haveli showcases the grandeur of Rajasthan’s rich history and intricate craftsmanship. The detailed carvings, exquisite balconies, and stunning jharokhas reflect the architectural brilliance of the bygone era.

The museum inside provides insightful details about the merchant families who once lived here, along with displays of traditional artifacts and paintings. The view from the top is breathtaking, offering a panoramic sight of Jaisalmer’s golden landscape.

A visit to this haveli feels like stepping back in time. If you love history and heritage, this place is definitely worth exploring !

Patwon Ki Haveli is absolutely breathtaking! The carvings on the walls and balconies are so detailed that you can spend hours just admiring the craftsmanship.

The entry fee is very minimal, and totally worth it. The best part for me was climbing up to the roof—you get an incredible view of the Jaisalmer Fort standing tall in the distance. It’s one of those picture-perfect moments you’ll want to capture.

The streets outside are buzzing with life, full of stalls selling colorful handicrafts and souvenirs.

Tip: Go a little early in the day before it gets too crowded, and don’t miss the rooftop view!

A Fascinating Glimpse into Jaisalmer’s Heritage! Kothari’s Patwon Ki Haveli is a must-visit when in Jaisalmer! This beautifully preserved haveli showcases the grandeur of Rajasthan’s rich history and intricate craftsmanship. The detailed carvings, exquisite balconies, and stunning jharokhas reflect the architectural brilliance of the bygone era.

Museum and Artifacts: The museum inside provides insightful details about the merchant families who once lived here, along with displays of traditional artifacts and paintings. The interiors hold a treasure trove of old letters, artifacts, and remnants from the British era, offering a rare glimpse into the lifestyle, trade practices, and social dynamics of that period.

Architecture and Craftsmanship: Built in the early 19th century by the wealthy Patwa family, this haveli is a testament to their immense wealth and influence. Each of the five havelis took around 12 years to complete and showcase unparalleled craftsmanship. Remarkably, these grand structures were built without cement or iron, relying solely on the ingenious rock-locking technique—a testament to the engineering brilliance of the time. The craftsmanship is simply stunning, with detailed facades, delicate balconies, and elaborate jali work.

Visitor Experience: A visit to this haveli feels like stepping back in time. If you love history and heritage, this place is definitely worth exploring. We got a guide who took us through the haveli, explaining everything. He charged us Rs. 50, but it was absolutely worth it. It took us about 20 minutes to explore the place. The view from the top is breathtaking, offering a panoramic sight of Jaisalmer’s golden landscape. Tips for Visitors: Visit early in the morning or late afternoon to avoid crowds. Don’t miss the rooftop view; it’s absolutely worth it! A guide or audio tour enhances the experience significantly. Try not to go on public holidays or weekends as it's crowded and one may not enjoy taking photos. The market around the haveli offers good antiques and handcrafted items, though they can be a bit pricey.

Recommendation: Patwon Ki Haveli is a true architectural marvel in the heart of Jaisalmer. It’s a must-see for anyone interested in architecture and history. The haveli’s beautiful courtyards, finely carved windows, and stunning interiors make it a must-visit for anyone exploring the cultural legacy of Jaisalmer. Highly recommended!

Practical Information:
Entry Fee: ₹150 per person.
Guide Fee: ₹150.
Best Time to Visit: Early morning or late afternoon to avoid the heat and enjoy the golden glow of the fort.
Duration: Approximately 1 hour. Washrooms: Not available.
Parking: Not available.

Enjoy your visit to this magnificent piece of history!

Patwon Ki Haveli is a must-visit in Jaisalmer! The intricate carvings and detailed architecture are truly stunning. Each haveli tells a story of the city’s rich heritage. It can get a bit crowded, and a guide is helpful to understand the history better. Overall, a fascinating glimpse into Rajasthan’s royal past.

Good historical structure with detailed carvings on jaisalmeri marble. Artifacts are preserved well and guide explains everything in details. You should hire a guide to know the importance of this place.

One of the best places to visit after exploring Jaisalmer Fort. This haveli is truly stunning—an excellent example of intricate craftsmanship and historical beauty. Every corner reflects the rich heritage of Rajasthan. It's a perfect spot for history lovers and an ideal place to click beautiful photos. A must-visit!

#throwback2008

A sandstone fever dream carved sometime in the 1800s by a rich Jain trader with more gold than sense and clearly too much time on his hands. The first of five havelis commissioned by the Patwa brothers, this one got the VIP treatment and now doubles as a museum,slash,maze.

Inside? A lavish sprawl of jharokhas, mirror work, wall murals, and carved arches that scream “Look Ma, I’m rich!” Walk carefully not for safety, but because your neck will hurt from gawking upward the whole time. Don’t miss the brooding portrait of a long dead patriarch who seems disappointed in your footwear choices.

Took over 50 years to complete mostly because aesthetics clearly trumped practicality. Historically, this was where money met marble and eloped with ego.

And yes, there’s a room dedicated to antique fans and opium boxes.. because priorities.

Patwon Ki Haveli is one of the most fascinating places to visit in Jaisalmer and truly a masterpiece of architecture. The intricate carvings on the golden sandstone walls are breathtaking you can stand there for minutes just admiring the details. Inside, each haveli has its own charm, with courtyards, balconies, and rooms that reflect the rich lifestyle of the merchants who once lived here. Walking through the narrow passages feels like stepping back in time, and the stories from the guides make the experience even more alive. It can get a little crowded, but the beauty and history here are so unique that it’s absolutely worth it. For me, Patwon Ki Haveli was like exploring a living museum of Jaisalmer’s golden past.

Jaisalmer Fort is truly a unique experience! The architecture is stunning and full of intricate details that make you appreciate the craftsmanship of the past. What makes it even more special is that it’s not just a fort – it’s like a living village inside. You’ll find homes, shops, and small streets that give it a lively and authentic feel. Walking through it feels like stepping back in time. Definitely a must-visit in Jaisalmer!

Jaisalmer Fort is not just a monument, it’s a living, breathing heritage site. Unlike most forts in India, people still reside inside, making it feel like a golden city within a fort. The yellow sandstone walls glow beautifully at sunrise and sunset, giving it the name “Sonar Quila” (Golden Fort).

Inside, you’ll find narrow lanes full of vibrant shops, handicrafts, rooftop cafes with stunning views, ancient Jain temples, and historic havelis. Exploring it feels like stepping back in time.

✔️ Must-do:

Visit during sunset for breathtaking golden hues.

Explore Jain Temples (intricate carvings).

Walk through the local markets for souvenirs.

Try a rooftop café for city views.

⚠️ Tips:

Wear comfortable footwear (lots of walking on stone paths).

Hire a local guide to know the hidden stories.

Early morning or evening visits are best to avoid heat.

Overall, Jaisalmer Fort is a unique experience – a UNESCO World Heritage site where history, culture, and daily life blend seamlessly. A must-visit if you’re in Rajasthan!

Sonar Kila, also known as Jaisalmer Fort, is one of the most magnificent forts in India and a true architectural wonder. Built with yellow sandstone, the fort glows like gold under sunlight, which is why it’s called “Sonar Kila”. Its massive walls, intricate carvings, and royal gateways reflect the rich heritage and craftsmanship of Rajasthan.

During my Jaisalmer visit, unfortunately, I couldn’t explore the fort from the inside due to time limitations, but I managed to capture some beautiful night-time photos from outside. The fort looks even more mesmerizing at night when it’s beautifully lit, creating a magical view.

Next time, I definitely plan to explore the fort from inside, as it’s home to historic palaces, Jain temples, and vibrant markets. Even if you can’t go inside, I highly recommend visiting Sonar Kila at least once to witness its majestic beauty from the outside — it’s truly unforgettable!

reviews.reviewText:
Gadisar Lake, Jaisalmer – A Serene Oasis in the Golden City

Gadisar Lake, located on the outskirts of Jaisalmer, Rajasthan, is one of the most picturesque and historically significant attractions of the city. This artificial lake, originally built in the 14th century by Maharawal Gadsi Singh, was once the primary source of water for the arid region. Today, it stands as a beautiful blend of history, architecture, and natural beauty, drawing tourists from all over the world.

Scenic Beauty and Atmosphere

The first thing that strikes you about Gadisar Lake is its breathtaking beauty. Surrounded by stunning yellow sandstone temples, ghats, and intricately carved chhatris (cenotaphs), the lake offers a postcard-perfect view, especially during sunrise and sunset. The calm waters of the lake reflect the golden hues of Jaisalmer’s architecture, creating a mesmerizing scene.

The lake is home to a variety of migratory birds, especially during the winter season. Bird watchers can spot species like cranes, pelicans, and kingfishers, making it a paradise for nature lovers. The gentle ripples in the water, combined with the chirping of birds and the occasional sound of temple bells, create a peaceful and soothing environment.

Boating Experience

One of the highlights of visiting Gadisar Lake is the boating experience. Paddle boats and rowboats are available, allowing visitors to explore the lake at a leisurely pace. As you glide across the water, you get an up-close view of the stunning structures that surround the lake. The reflections of the chhatris and temples in the water make for some truly amazing photo opportunities.

Boating is best enjoyed during the early morning or late evening when the weather is pleasant, and the golden light enhances the beauty of the surroundings. The experience is both relaxing and romantic, making it perfect for couples, families, and solo travelers alike.

Architectural Marvels and Temples

The lake is not just a scenic spot but also a place of historical and architectural significance. The Tilon Ki Pol, an elaborately carved sandstone gateway at the entrance of the lake, adds to its charm. According to legend, this gateway was built by a royal courtesan, Tilon, despite opposition from the ruling king. It is believed that she cleverly built a temple of Lord Krishna on top of the gate, ensuring that it would never be demolished.

Several small temples and shrines dedicated to Hindu deities line the lake’s periphery, adding to its spiritual aura. The intricate carvings on the sandstone structures reflect the rich craftsmanship of Rajasthan and are a testament to Jaisalmer’s glorious past.

Best Time to Visit

The best time to visit Gadisar Lake is during the winter months (October to March) when the weather is pleasant and ideal for sightseeing and boating. Summers in Jaisalmer can be extremely hot, making it difficult to enjoy outdoor activities. Early mornings and evenings are the best times to experience the lake’s beauty, as the golden sunlight creates a magical effect on the water and surrounding architecture.

A peaceful and scenic spot in the heart of Jaisalmer! Gadisar Lake is perfect for a relaxing boat ride, especially during sunrise or sunset. Surrounded by beautifully carved temples and ghats, it’s a great place for photography and quiet reflection. A must-visit for nature lovers and those looking to unwind away from the desert heat.
Place is beautiful but needs a little maintenance. Boat ride is enjoyable. I will Recommend morning time visit

Gadisar Lake – A Scenic and Historic Escape in Jaisalmer

Gadisar Lake is more than just a picturesque spot in Jaisalmer—it’s a place steeped in history and cultural significance. Built in the 14th century by Maharawal Gadsi Singh, this artificial reservoir was once the primary water source for the city. The beautifully carved temples, cenotaphs, and ghats surrounding it add to its old-world charm. The grand entrance, Tilon Ki Pol, has an interesting backstory—it was built by a courtesan, and to prevent its demolition, she had a Krishna temple constructed atop it.

Even though it no longer serves as Jaisalmer’s main water source, the lake remains a serene retreat. The reflections of the golden-hued architecture on the calm waters, the sight of migratory birds in winter, and the option to enjoy a boat ride make it a must-visit. The atmosphere is peaceful, making it perfect for an early morning or sunset visit.

Whether you're interested in history, photography, or just want to enjoy a quiet moment by the water, Gadisar Lake is a delightful stop in Jaisalmer.

Visited in 2019 during our college excursion, my visit to Gadisar Lake was one of the most peaceful and enriching experiences in Jaisalmer. Nestled on the edge of the city, this man-made lake was originally built in the 14th century by Maharawal Gadsi Singh to serve as a water conservation tank for the arid desert region. Beyond its practical purpose, the lake today stands as a beautiful blend of history, architecture, and natural serenity.

Surrounded by intricately carved chhatris (cenotaphs), temples, and ghats, the lake reflects the architectural grace of Rajasthan. The calm waters, especially during sunrise or sunset, create a picture-perfect scene with the golden hues of Jaisalmer glowing in the background. As a history student, what fascinated me most was how such water bodies played a crucial role in desert life, not just for survival, but also as spaces for worship, community gatherings, and cultural expression.

Boating on the lake gave a closer look at the structures scattered across the water—reminders of the city's glorious past. Gadisar Lake is not just a tourist spot; it’s a historical site that tells the story of sustainable living and the spiritual connection between nature and culture in Rajasthan’s desert heartland.

Gadsisar Lake is one of Jaisalmer's most beautiful and quiet locations. The lake exudes a tranquil and relaxing atmosphere, ideal for spending time with friends and family. There is also a Shiv Mandir nearby where you can receive blessings and enjoy a spiritual ambiance. Boating facilities are available, and the views from the boat are simply breathtaking, particularly at sunrise and sunset.

When I arrived, there was a Teej Mela going on, which made the atmosphere bright and energetic. Due to the fair, the throng was large, but it added to the joyous atmosphere. There were various vendors selling traditional things, toys, local handicrafts, cuisine, and decorative items – ideal for those who enjoy shopping.

Gadisar Lake is a peaceful and beautiful spot in Jaisalmer. The view of the temples and ghats around the lake is amazing, especially at sunrise and sunset. You can enjoy a boat ride and soak in the calm atmosphere. It’s not just scenic but also feels very serene and refreshing away from the hustle of the city. A perfect place to relax and click some great pictures!
Beautiful spot to visit,  nice to find a quiet spot beside the lake in the evening and watch the pleasant scenery.

Jaisalmer Fort is truly a unique experience! The architecture is stunning and full of intricate details that make you appreciate the craftsmanship of the past. What makes it even more special is that it’s not just a fort – it’s like a living village inside. You’ll find homes, shops, and small streets that give it a lively and authentic feel. Walking through it feels like stepping back in time. Definitely a must-visit in Jaisalmer!

Jaisalmer Fort is not just a monument, it’s a living, breathing heritage site. Unlike most forts in India, people still reside inside, making it feel like a golden city within a fort. The yellow sandstone walls glow beautifully at sunrise and sunset, giving it the name “Sonar Quila” (Golden Fort).

Inside, you’ll find narrow lanes full of vibrant shops, handicrafts, rooftop cafes with stunning views, ancient Jain temples, and historic havelis. Exploring it feels like stepping back in time.

✔️ Must-do:

Visit during sunset for breathtaking golden hues.

Explore Jain Temples (intricate carvings).

Walk through the local markets for souvenirs.

Try a rooftop café for city views.

⚠️ Tips:

Wear comfortable footwear (lots of walking on stone paths).

Hire a local guide to know the hidden stories.

Early morning or evening visits are best to avoid heat.

Overall, Jaisalmer Fort is a unique experience – a UNESCO World Heritage site where history, culture, and daily life blend seamlessly. A must-visit if you’re in Rajasthan!

Sonar Kila, also known as Jaisalmer Fort, is one of the most magnificent forts in India and a true architectural wonder. Built with yellow sandstone, the fort glows like gold under sunlight, which is why it’s called “Sonar Kila”. Its massive walls, intricate carvings, and royal gateways reflect the rich heritage and craftsmanship of Rajasthan.

During my Jaisalmer visit, unfortunately, I couldn’t explore the fort from the inside due to time limitations, but I managed to capture some beautiful night-time photos from outside. The fort looks even more mesmerizing at night when it’s beautifully lit, creating a magical view.

Next time, I definitely plan to explore the fort from inside, as it’s home to historic palaces, Jain temples, and vibrant markets. Even if you can’t go inside, I highly recommend visiting Sonar Kila at least once to witness its majestic beauty from the outside — it’s truly unforgettable!

Nestled in the heart of Jaisalmer, just 2 km from the iconic Jaisalmer Fort, **Mandir Palace**, also known as **Badal Vilas**, offers a fascinating blend of history, heritage, and hospitality. This magnificent palace, still partially serving as the residence of the royal family, transports visitors to a bygone era of Rajput grandeur.

Architectural Charm & Heritage
The exterior of Mandir Palace is a striking example of traditional **Rajputana architecture**, featuring ornately carved facades, jharokhas, and intricately designed archways. Its golden sandstone structure glows in the sunlight, making it a favorite for photography and heritage enthusiasts alike.

Inside, parts of the palace function as a **museum**, displaying a modest collection of royal artifacts, weapons, and historical relics. While not extensive, it provides a brief insight into Jaisalmer’s royal lineage.

**rooftop view**—offering stunning panoramas of the **Jaisalmer Fort**, the Golden City, and the **Thar Desert**, especially at sunrise and sunset.

Visiting Experience & Entry Fees
Museum comes at a fee of approximately **₹160–₹250**, with an additional **₹30** for mobile photography. While the architecture is beautiful, the **museum section is relatively small**, and some might find it underwhelming if expecting a large exhibit.

Overall Impression
Mandir Palace / Badal Vilas is not just a structure—it's a **living piece of Jaisalmer's royal legacy**. While the museum might not justify the ticket price for every visitor, the architectural beauty, tranquil atmosphere, and regal charm still make it a **worthwhile stop**, especially for those interested in heritage and history.

Mandir Palace, also known as Badal Vilas, offers a captivating blend of heritage and hospitality that immerses visitors in the rich history of Jaisalmer. Our stay at this majestic palace was a journey through time, where the walls echoed tales of a bygone era.

The architecture of Mandir Palace is a testament to the opulence of Rajputana design. Intricately carved facades, delicate jharokhas, and regal archways transport guests to an era of grandeur. The palace's seamless integration with its historical surroundings enhances its allure, creating an oasis of splendor in the heart of the Golden City.

Our accommodations at Badal Vilas were nothing short of regal. The rooms, adorned with traditional Rajasthani decor, provided a perfect blend of comfort and antiquity. The attention to detail in the furnishings and the preservation of the palace's historical elements added a touch of authenticity to our stay.

One of the highlights of our visit was the exquisite dining experience. The palace's restaurant served a delectable array of Rajasthani and international cuisines. The culinary journey was elevated by the elegant setting, and the attentive staff ensured a dining experience that matched the grandeur of the palace.

The palace staff deserves commendation for their impeccable service. From the warm welcome at the entrance to the prompt and courteous assistance throughout our stay, the hospitality at Mandir Palace exemplifies the legendary Rajput hospitality.

The rooftop views at Badal Vilas were nothing short of breathtaking. The panoramic vistas of Jaisalmer Fort, the cityscape, and the vast Thar Desert painted a mesmerizing picture, especially during sunrise and sunset. These moments created memories that will linger long after our stay.

While Mandir Palace offers an enchanting experience, it's important to note that, like many historical establishments, there may be occasional maintenance challenges. However, the staff's quick response to address any concerns demonstrated their commitment to ensuring a comfortable stay for guests.

In conclusion, Mandir Palace, or Badal Vilas, is more than a hotel; it's a journey into the grandeur of Jaisalmer's history. The palace's architectural splendor, luxurious accommodations, delectable cuisine, and warm hospitality make it a destination that transcends the ordinary. Our stay at Mandir Palace was not just a visit; it was an immersive experience in the regal charm of Rajasthan's heritage.

sources.snippet: Tazia Tower, located in Jaisalmer, India, is an impressive example of Rajasthani architecture and culture. This five-story tower is an integral part of the Badal Mahal (Palace of Clouds) complex and embodies the artistic flair and intricate craftsmanship that is characteristic of the region. Built-in the 19th century, the Tazia Tower serves as a memorial for the Tazias, which are ornate replicas of the tomb of the Prophet Muhammad, traditionally used during the festive observance of Muharram.

reviews.reviewText:
Must added  in  your  Jaisalmer  trip😍
This place is absolutely stunning—a true picture-perfect spot that feels like it belongs in a painting. The beauty of the lake is mesmerizing, especially as the sun sets, casting a golden glow across the water. The colors in the sky blend so effortlessly, making it a perfect backdrop for a peaceful evening. The surrounding area is filled with beautiful artwork, enhancing the natural beauty and creating a serene atmosphere. It’s the ideal location to relax and soak in the views, with the artwork adding a unique touch that makes it even more special. Truly a place to spend quality time and appreciate both nature and art at their finest.

Must-Visit Spot in Jaisalmer: Gadisar Lake 🌅✨

Gadisar Lake (also known as Gadsisar Lake) is an absolute gem that should be on every traveler’s Jaisalmer itinerary. Located just 1.5 km from the Jaisalmer Fort, this historic artificial reservoir dates back to 1156 AD, originally built by King Rawal Jaisal and later reconstructed by Gadsi Singh Bhati in 1367 AD.

From the moment you arrive, the serene beauty of the lake is captivating. As the sun begins to set, the golden light reflects off the water, creating a dreamy, picture-perfect scene that feels straight out of a painting. The sky transforms into a canvas of soft, blended hues—ideal for a peaceful evening stroll or capturing some stunning photographs.

Surrounding the lake are intricately carved temples, shrines, and cenotaphs (chhatris), showcasing the rich architectural heritage of Rajasthan. The atmosphere here blends natural beauty with artistic charm, making it a tranquil yet culturally enriching experience.

Things to Do:
Boating: Pedal and row boats are available, offering a calm ride across the lake. Prices range from ₹100 for a 2-seater pedal boat to ₹300 for a 6-seater rowboat.
Wildlife Watching: Spot catfish near the shore and enjoy watching migratory birds—perfect for nature lovers and photographers.
Sunset Views & Light Show: Arrive by 5 PM to find a good spot on the steps near the waterfront. Watch the mesmerizing sunset, followed by a light and sound show at 6:45 PM (entry included with fort ticket).
Street Food & Local Cuisine: Don’t miss the vibrant food stalls nearby offering delicious and affordable local snacks. Also try the well-known 1156 AD multi-cuisine restaurant for a more relaxed dining experience.

Key Info:
Timings: Open daily from 8:00 AM to 7:00 PM.
Entry Fee: No entry fee required. Parking is available (paid).
Facilities: Several shops at the entry point. However, washroom facilities were not visible, which could be improved.
Water Source: The lake is maintained through the Indira Gandhi Canal, ensuring it remains full year-round.

Final Thoughts:
While there is some room for improvement in terms of cleanliness, Gadisar Lake remains a must-visit. The combination of history, art, nature, and local flavor makes it a unique and unforgettable destination in the heart of Jaisalmer. Whether you're looking to relax, explore, or indulge in Rajasthani culture, this peaceful lakeside spot offers it all.

Highly recommended for an evening outing!

Gadisar Lake is Jaisalmer’s answer to “what if we put a tranquil oasis in the middle of the Thar Desert, and added a bunch of temples swans and paddle boats for good measure?” Built in the 14th century by Maharawal Gadsi Singh, this manmade lake once served as the city’s lifeline, now it’s more of a selfie magnet with bonus ducks.

Early morning or sunset is when the magic kicks in, golden light bouncing off yellow sandstone chhatris reflected in still waters like the desert decided to get poetic. You’ll find temples shrines and steps leading down into the lake, often with local kids attempting acrobatics off them while pigeons judge from above.

Paddle boats are available if you’re feeling brave (or bored) and the vibe is equal parts peaceful and theatrical, think Venice if Venice had camels loitering at the entrance.

Not sacred but oddly serene, Gadisar Lake is where Jaisalmer exhales, quietly beautifully and sometimes with a light fishy smell.

Good shop with  huge variety. Was taken there by our driver…..
No bargaining option..,
On our first day of our visit we bought an item for a particular price . On next day we went to buy same items again for a neighbor. Then they were charging 2 times than the first purchase!!! I even showed the original bill of last purchase. Still they did not come down .

Purchased 3 so called camel wool blankets(3k each) and 2 sarees for around 13k . Camel wool blankets particularly that they sell you are  fake blankets with synthetic fabric (similar to fabric in wakefit pillows) stuffed in them . Stitching is poor with fake wool coming out of the blanket. Your cab driver general takes you to these kind of Shops, Please avoid going to this shop and purchasing anything.

Totally fraud shop. Price is at least 5 times  more than the normal market price. The salesmen are big cons. They will claim all the items are special. There is nothing special and most of the items are available online and other local shops. A normal printed kurti set which is available at Rs 600 online is priced at Rs 4000. A double bed Rasai which is available online at Rs800 rs is priced as Rs 7500. Moreover none of the price is written in the item and they will claim it is a fixed price shop. Neither they provide a GST bill. They will claim all the items are very special item from Jaisalmer and blah blah blah.
Avoid this shop if you don't want to be frauded.

I had worst experience at this shop..they just fool us and charge much more than the actual price. I purchased hapur stone from there and it is totally useless and i also purchased a quilt which they claimed to be made of camel wool but it is made of fiber. Don't fall for such fake items.

Dont buy anything from this shop. As Drivers/tour guide have commission with them, they will definitely take you to this place.

Over priced place with no bargains. You will get better quality product in other near by shops on below half price. Dont fall for the scam they are doing here.

Very arrogant and full of attitude staff. Metal Mina work horse, the one they are charging 8,000/- same I buy for 2750/- outside.

So think before buying here.

One hand made table top they are charging 3000/- same ai buy for 900/- outside.

Try to visit local market, local shops, walk around the fort to buy things.

Souvenir, clothes, blankets, leather, jewellery everything is expensive here.

Advice for shop, stop stealing money from your customers. Start providing fare price and single price to all. Me and my wife shopping separately you told me price 5000/- and my wife 3800/- how that is possible for one same product. So do a fare job. Dont corrupt the jaisalmer local business.

Thank you!

Overpriced and Misleading - Avoid This Shop

We were taken to this shop by our driver, and it turned out to be a disappointing experience. There is no room for bargaining, and the prices are highly inflated. It was evident that the driver received a commission from our purchase.

We bought four sarees for ₹10,000, only to find the same sarees available for ₹5,000-₹6,000 in smaller shops at the fort. The salespeople at this shop made false promises and provided misleading information to entice us into buying. Their only aim seems to be trapping customers with lies to sell overpriced items.

Avoid falling into the trap of this shop. Take your time to explore smaller, local shops where you can find the same items at much more reasonable prices.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we’re always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Jaisalmer, often referred to as the 'Golden City,' is a mesmerizing blend of history and architectural brilliance nestled in the heart of the Thar Desert. As you wander through its narrow lanes, you'll be captivated by the stunning sandstone structures that seem to glow under the sun, each telling a story of the city's rich heritage. From the majestic Jaisalmer Fort, a UNESCO World Heritage site, to the intricately carved havelis like Nathmal Ki Haveli and Patwon Ki Haveli, the city is a treasure trove for architecture enthusiasts and casual travelers alike.

The Wanderlog team is passionate about uncovering the unique charm of Jaisalmer's architectural wonders. Whether you're exploring the ornate Jain temples within the fort or admiring the delicate craftsmanship of the Tazia Tower, each site offers a glimpse into the artistic prowess of the region. Don't miss the chance to visit the serene Vyas Chhatri at sunset or the vibrant Silk Route Art Gallery, where you can find exquisite handicrafts. Jaisalmer's architectural landscape is waiting to be explored, inviting you to immerse yourself in its beauty and history.

sources.snippet: Built by wealthy Jain merchants during the 19th century, these grand havelis provide an insight into their opulent lifestyle from bygone years. From intricate carvings, beautiful facades, and ornamental balconies adorning each haveli to ornamental balconies that extend, Patwon Ki Haveli provides endless photographic opportunities. From its unique blend of Rajasthani and Mughal architectural styles - offering various opportunities for photography; to mesmerising shadows on intricately carved sandstone facades that create mesmerising effects - perfect for capturing unforgettable moments that will stand the test of time!

sources.snippet: Patwon Ki Haveli, a cluster of five elaborately designed mansions, exemplifies the artistic brilliance of Jaisalmer’s bygone era. Each haveli boasts unique architectural nuances, featuring intricate carvings, lattice windows, and ornate balconies. Step into a world of opulence as you document the captivating symphony of colors and patterns that adorn these historical gems, capturing the essence of a regal lifestyle frozen in time.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Patwon Ki Haveli, also known as Patwa Haveli, is a series of palaces from the early 1800s that have been transformed into a museum showcasing intricate carvings, furniture, and artwork. These grand havelis were built by wealthy Jain merchants during the 19th century and offer a glimpse into their lavish lifestyle.
placeMetadata.address: No. 3129, Opposite Choora Paada, Rajasthan 345001, India

reviews.reviewText:
A Fascinating Glimpse into Jaisalmer’s Heritage!

Kothari’s Patwon Ki Haveli is a must-visit when in Jaisalmer! This beautifully preserved haveli showcases the grandeur of Rajasthan’s rich history and intricate craftsmanship. The detailed carvings, exquisite balconies, and stunning jharokhas reflect the architectural brilliance of the bygone era.

The museum inside provides insightful details about the merchant families who once lived here, along with displays of traditional artifacts and paintings. The view from the top is breathtaking, offering a panoramic sight of Jaisalmer’s golden landscape.

A visit to this haveli feels like stepping back in time. If you love history and heritage, this place is definitely worth exploring !

Patwon Ki Haveli is absolutely breathtaking! The carvings on the walls and balconies are so detailed that you can spend hours just admiring the craftsmanship.

The entry fee is very minimal, and totally worth it. The best part for me was climbing up to the roof—you get an incredible view of the Jaisalmer Fort standing tall in the distance. It’s one of those picture-perfect moments you’ll want to capture.

The streets outside are buzzing with life, full of stalls selling colorful handicrafts and souvenirs.

Tip: Go a little early in the day before it gets too crowded, and don’t miss the rooftop view!

A Fascinating Glimpse into Jaisalmer’s Heritage! Kothari’s Patwon Ki Haveli is a must-visit when in Jaisalmer! This beautifully preserved haveli showcases the grandeur of Rajasthan’s rich history and intricate craftsmanship. The detailed carvings, exquisite balconies, and stunning jharokhas reflect the architectural brilliance of the bygone era.

Museum and Artifacts: The museum inside provides insightful details about the merchant families who once lived here, along with displays of traditional artifacts and paintings. The interiors hold a treasure trove of old letters, artifacts, and remnants from the British era, offering a rare glimpse into the lifestyle, trade practices, and social dynamics of that period.

Architecture and Craftsmanship: Built in the early 19th century by the wealthy Patwa family, this haveli is a testament to their immense wealth and influence. Each of the five havelis took around 12 years to complete and showcase unparalleled craftsmanship. Remarkably, these grand structures were built without cement or iron, relying solely on the ingenious rock-locking technique—a testament to the engineering brilliance of the time. The craftsmanship is simply stunning, with detailed facades, delicate balconies, and elaborate jali work.

Visitor Experience: A visit to this haveli feels like stepping back in time. If you love history and heritage, this place is definitely worth exploring. We got a guide who took us through the haveli, explaining everything. He charged us Rs. 50, but it was absolutely worth it. It took us about 20 minutes to explore the place. The view from the top is breathtaking, offering a panoramic sight of Jaisalmer’s golden landscape. Tips for Visitors: Visit early in the morning or late afternoon to avoid crowds. Don’t miss the rooftop view; it’s absolutely worth it! A guide or audio tour enhances the experience significantly. Try not to go on public holidays or weekends as it's crowded and one may not enjoy taking photos. The market around the haveli offers good antiques and handcrafted items, though they can be a bit pricey.

Recommendation: Patwon Ki Haveli is a true architectural marvel in the heart of Jaisalmer. It’s a must-see for anyone interested in architecture and history. The haveli’s beautiful courtyards, finely carved windows, and stunning interiors make it a must-visit for anyone exploring the cultural legacy of Jaisalmer. Highly recommended!

Practical Information:
Entry Fee: ₹150 per person.
Guide Fee: ₹150.
Best Time to Visit: Early morning or late afternoon to avoid the heat and enjoy the golden glow of the fort.
Duration: Approximately 1 hour. Washrooms: Not available.
Parking: Not available.

Enjoy your visit to this magnificent piece of history!

Patwon Ki Haveli is a must-visit in Jaisalmer! The intricate carvings and detailed architecture are truly stunning. Each haveli tells a story of the city’s rich heritage. It can get a bit crowded, and a guide is helpful to understand the history better. Overall, a fascinating glimpse into Rajasthan’s royal past.

Good historical structure with detailed carvings on jaisalmeri marble. Artifacts are preserved well and guide explains everything in details. You should hire a guide to know the importance of this place.

One of the best places to visit after exploring Jaisalmer Fort. This haveli is truly stunning—an excellent example of intricate craftsmanship and historical beauty. Every corner reflects the rich heritage of Rajasthan. It's a perfect spot for history lovers and an ideal place to click beautiful photos. A must-visit!

#throwback2008

A sandstone fever dream carved sometime in the 1800s by a rich Jain trader with more gold than sense and clearly too much time on his hands. The first of five havelis commissioned by the Patwa brothers, this one got the VIP treatment and now doubles as a museum,slash,maze.

Inside? A lavish sprawl of jharokhas, mirror work, wall murals, and carved arches that scream “Look Ma, I’m rich!” Walk carefully not for safety, but because your neck will hurt from gawking upward the whole time. Don’t miss the brooding portrait of a long dead patriarch who seems disappointed in your footwear choices.

Took over 50 years to complete mostly because aesthetics clearly trumped practicality. Historically, this was where money met marble and eloped with ego.

And yes, there’s a room dedicated to antique fans and opium boxes.. because priorities.

Patwon Ki Haveli is one of the most fascinating places to visit in Jaisalmer and truly a masterpiece of architecture. The intricate carvings on the golden sandstone walls are breathtaking you can stand there for minutes just admiring the details. Inside, each haveli has its own charm, with courtyards, balconies, and rooms that reflect the rich lifestyle of the merchants who once lived here. Walking through the narrow passages feels like stepping back in time, and the stories from the guides make the experience even more alive. It can get a little crowded, but the beauty and history here are so unique that it’s absolutely worth it. For me, Patwon Ki Haveli was like exploring a living museum of Jaisalmer’s golden past.

Jaisalmer Fort is truly a unique experience! The architecture is stunning and full of intricate details that make you appreciate the craftsmanship of the past. What makes it even more special is that it’s not just a fort – it’s like a living village inside. You’ll find homes, shops, and small streets that give it a lively and authentic feel. Walking through it feels like stepping back in time. Definitely a must-visit in Jaisalmer!

Jaisalmer Fort is not just a monument, it’s a living, breathing heritage site. Unlike most forts in India, people still reside inside, making it feel like a golden city within a fort. The yellow sandstone walls glow beautifully at sunrise and sunset, giving it the name “Sonar Quila” (Golden Fort).

Inside, you’ll find narrow lanes full of vibrant shops, handicrafts, rooftop cafes with stunning views, ancient Jain temples, and historic havelis. Exploring it feels like stepping back in time.

✔️ Must-do:

Visit during sunset for breathtaking golden hues.

Explore Jain Temples (intricate carvings).

Walk through the local markets for souvenirs.

Try a rooftop café for city views.

⚠️ Tips:

Wear comfortable footwear (lots of walking on stone paths).

Hire a local guide to know the hidden stories.

Early morning or evening visits are best to avoid heat.

Overall, Jaisalmer Fort is a unique experience – a UNESCO World Heritage site where history, culture, and daily life blend seamlessly. A must-visit if you’re in Rajasthan!

Sonar Kila, also known as Jaisalmer Fort, is one of the most magnificent forts in India and a true architectural wonder. Built with yellow sandstone, the fort glows like gold under sunlight, which is why it’s called “Sonar Kila”. Its massive walls, intricate carvings, and royal gateways reflect the rich heritage and craftsmanship of Rajasthan.

During my Jaisalmer visit, unfortunately, I couldn’t explore the fort from the inside due to time limitations, but I managed to capture some beautiful night-time photos from outside. The fort looks even more mesmerizing at night when it’s beautifully lit, creating a magical view.

Next time, I definitely plan to explore the fort from inside, as it’s home to historic palaces, Jain temples, and vibrant markets. Even if you can’t go inside, I highly recommend visiting Sonar Kila at least once to witness its majestic beauty from the outside — it’s truly unforgettable!

reviews.reviewText:
Gadisar Lake, Jaisalmer – A Serene Oasis in the Golden City

Gadisar Lake, located on the outskirts of Jaisalmer, Rajasthan, is one of the most picturesque and historically significant attractions of the city. This artificial lake, originally built in the 14th century by Maharawal Gadsi Singh, was once the primary source of water for the arid region. Today, it stands as a beautiful blend of history, architecture, and natural beauty, drawing tourists from all over the world.

Scenic Beauty and Atmosphere

The first thing that strikes you about Gadisar Lake is its breathtaking beauty. Surrounded by stunning yellow sandstone temples, ghats, and intricately carved chhatris (cenotaphs), the lake offers a postcard-perfect view, especially during sunrise and sunset. The calm waters of the lake reflect the golden hues of Jaisalmer’s architecture, creating a mesmerizing scene.

The lake is home to a variety of migratory birds, especially during the winter season. Bird watchers can spot species like cranes, pelicans, and kingfishers, making it a paradise for nature lovers. The gentle ripples in the water, combined with the chirping of birds and the occasional sound of temple bells, create a peaceful and soothing environment.

Boating Experience

One of the highlights of visiting Gadisar Lake is the boating experience. Paddle boats and rowboats are available, allowing visitors to explore the lake at a leisurely pace. As you glide across the water, you get an up-close view of the stunning structures that surround the lake. The reflections of the chhatris and temples in the water make for some truly amazing photo opportunities.

Boating is best enjoyed during the early morning or late evening when the weather is pleasant, and the golden light enhances the beauty of the surroundings. The experience is both relaxing and romantic, making it perfect for couples, families, and solo travelers alike.

Architectural Marvels and Temples

The lake is not just a scenic spot but also a place of historical and architectural significance. The Tilon Ki Pol, an elaborately carved sandstone gateway at the entrance of the lake, adds to its charm. According to legend, this gateway was built by a royal courtesan, Tilon, despite opposition from the ruling king. It is believed that she cleverly built a temple of Lord Krishna on top of the gate, ensuring that it would never be demolished.

Several small temples and shrines dedicated to Hindu deities line the lake’s periphery, adding to its spiritual aura. The intricate carvings on the sandstone structures reflect the rich craftsmanship of Rajasthan and are a testament to Jaisalmer’s glorious past.

Best Time to Visit

The best time to visit Gadisar Lake is during the winter months (October to March) when the weather is pleasant and ideal for sightseeing and boating. Summers in Jaisalmer can be extremely hot, making it difficult to enjoy outdoor activities. Early mornings and evenings are the best times to experience the lake’s beauty, as the golden sunlight creates a magical effect on the water and surrounding architecture.

A peaceful and scenic spot in the heart of Jaisalmer! Gadisar Lake is perfect for a relaxing boat ride, especially during sunrise or sunset. Surrounded by beautifully carved temples and ghats, it’s a great place for photography and quiet reflection. A must-visit for nature lovers and those looking to unwind away from the desert heat.
Place is beautiful but needs a little maintenance. Boat ride is enjoyable. I will Recommend morning time visit

Gadisar Lake – A Scenic and Historic Escape in Jaisalmer

Gadisar Lake is more than just a picturesque spot in Jaisalmer—it’s a place steeped in history and cultural significance. Built in the 14th century by Maharawal Gadsi Singh, this artificial reservoir was once the primary water source for the city. The beautifully carved temples, cenotaphs, and ghats surrounding it add to its old-world charm. The grand entrance, Tilon Ki Pol, has an interesting backstory—it was built by a courtesan, and to prevent its demolition, she had a Krishna temple constructed atop it.

Even though it no longer serves as Jaisalmer’s main water source, the lake remains a serene retreat. The reflections of the golden-hued architecture on the calm waters, the sight of migratory birds in winter, and the option to enjoy a boat ride make it a must-visit. The atmosphere is peaceful, making it perfect for an early morning or sunset visit.

Whether you're interested in history, photography, or just want to enjoy a quiet moment by the water, Gadisar Lake is a delightful stop in Jaisalmer.

Visited in 2019 during our college excursion, my visit to Gadisar Lake was one of the most peaceful and enriching experiences in Jaisalmer. Nestled on the edge of the city, this man-made lake was originally built in the 14th century by Maharawal Gadsi Singh to serve as a water conservation tank for the arid desert region. Beyond its practical purpose, the lake today stands as a beautiful blend of history, architecture, and natural serenity.

Surrounded by intricately carved chhatris (cenotaphs), temples, and ghats, the lake reflects the architectural grace of Rajasthan. The calm waters, especially during sunrise or sunset, create a picture-perfect scene with the golden hues of Jaisalmer glowing in the background. As a history student, what fascinated me most was how such water bodies played a crucial role in desert life, not just for survival, but also as spaces for worship, community gatherings, and cultural expression.

Boating on the lake gave a closer look at the structures scattered across the water—reminders of the city's glorious past. Gadisar Lake is not just a tourist spot; it’s a historical site that tells the story of sustainable living and the spiritual connection between nature and culture in Rajasthan’s desert heartland.

Gadsisar Lake is one of Jaisalmer's most beautiful and quiet locations. The lake exudes a tranquil and relaxing atmosphere, ideal for spending time with friends and family. There is also a Shiv Mandir nearby where you can receive blessings and enjoy a spiritual ambiance. Boating facilities are available, and the views from the boat are simply breathtaking, particularly at sunrise and sunset.

When I arrived, there was a Teej Mela going on, which made the atmosphere bright and energetic. Due to the fair, the throng was large, but it added to the joyous atmosphere. There were various vendors selling traditional things, toys, local handicrafts, cuisine, and decorative items – ideal for those who enjoy shopping.

Gadisar Lake is a peaceful and beautiful spot in Jaisalmer. The view of the temples and ghats around the lake is amazing, especially at sunrise and sunset. You can enjoy a boat ride and soak in the calm atmosphere. It’s not just scenic but also feels very serene and refreshing away from the hustle of the city. A perfect place to relax and click some great pictures!
Beautiful spot to visit,  nice to find a quiet spot beside the lake in the evening and watch the pleasant scenery.

Jaisalmer is known for beautiful havelis. This beautiful haveli is located in the heart of town in small lanes. It was built in 19th century by two brothers Nathmal and Hathi Singh. It is made up of yellow sandstone in true Rajasthani style. The beautiful carvings all over the buildings are worth seeing. A blend of Islamic and Rajputana architecture, Nathmal Ki Haveli is one of the most beautiful Havelis in Jaisalmer. This haveli has derived its origin from the late 19th century and has an extraordinary exterior that is filled with carvings. The left and right wings were the work of two brothers-Hathi and Lulu and their competitive spirit produced this magnificent piece of architecture. Apart from its extraordinary outer carvings, this haveli is known for its beautiful interiors.

Iconic Place at Jaisalmer
Do visit and appreciate our heritage

placeMetadata.name: The Thar Heritage Museum

sources.snippet: Displaying the rich culture, heritage and architectural style of Rajasthan, The Thar Heritage Museum falls in every best places to visit in Jaisalmer list. This historical reservoir houses a wide assortment of objects from ancient times, like musical instruments, different types of kitchen equipment, artefacts, fossils, turbans, coins and ornaments. The snakes and ladder game and a puppet show narrated by the museum’s curator Shri L.N. Khatri are quite entertaining and engaging.
sources.shortName: 31 Places to Visit in Jaisalmer That You Can Visit in 2024

sources.snippet: Built in the 12th century by the Bhati Rajput ruler Rao Jaisal, the Jaisalmer Fort is a massive yellow sandstone fortification that maintains the Raj Mahal and several havelis, gateways and temples. The tawny-brown rampart that turns into honey-gold at sunset, justifying the name “Sonar Quila”, is undoubtedly a blazing instance of visual perception.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Places to Visit in Jaisalmer, Rajasthan

sources.snippet: Founded by L Narayan Khatri, the Thar Heritage Museum is a historical reservoir. L Narayan was an eminent scholar of the Jaisalmer folklore. The museum not just tells you the times of Jaisalmer but also showcases the rich culture, heritage, folk art and architectural style of Rajasthan.
sources.shortName: 31 Best Places to visit in Jaisalmer | Top Tourist Attractions

placeMetadata.description: Compact museum offering guided tours of the historical collection featuring folk art & artifacts.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Thar Heritage Museum, established by local historian Laxmi Narayan Khatri, showcases a diverse collection of artifacts and folk art dedicated to Jaisalmer's desert heritage. The museum features ancient marine fossils, weaponry, manuscripts detailing trade between local merchants and Asian travelers, coins, paintings, utensils, instruments, costumes, and information about customs such as opium consumption and rituals for birth, marriage, and death.
placeMetadata.address: Gramin Haat, Ramgarh Rd, next to Vyas cenotaphs, ONGC Colony, Jaisalmer, Kishan Ghat, Rajasthan 345001, India

reviews.reviewText:
Lovely little museum with a variety of interesting bits from the thar desert. The museum founder gave us a tour and gave us some insight about all of the items. He's very hospitable and clearly passionate about preserving the history of the area.

Worth visiting if you're in Jaisalmer, especially if your at vyas chhatri.

It’s a very unique place removed from the city, but it was worthwhile the drive.
Run by M Khatri who is passionate about protecting folk art he takes you through the museum, explaining every piece and the stories behind them. At the end of the visit, we are able to admire textile pieces that he gets embroidered by the village  women and buy the ones that our heart desires.

More than a museum, it’s a whisper from the desert’s past. The Thar Heritage Museum isn’t just a place to see—it’s a place to feel. It’s a celebration of desert life, a tribute to forgotten stories, and a reminder that history lives not just in grand palaces but in humble homes and heartfelt tales.

A must-visit for anyone seeking the soul of Rajasthan beyond the sand dunes and forts.

An amazing collection of artifacts, paintings and tools and daily use items of various desert tribes and Royal families of Jaisalmer region, painstakingly collected for over 20 years by the very dedicated and passionate Mr LN Khatri, the owner of this private museum. He is a wonderful person to talk to who gives personal tours to every visitor if planned in advance. I totally loved exploring the awesome collection with Mr Khatri. He has been awarded many awards over the years for this collection and it's an honor to meet such a humble, passionate man. Totally worth a visit!!
Mr. L.N Khatri diaplays his personal collection in this museum.  He also gshares his knowledge about each object in the museum.  This place is close to Bada Bagh and is a must visit.

An informative cultural experience, praised for its knowledgeable owner-guides who provide personal tours of its collection of desert artifacts, manuscripts, coins, and photos. The passion of its curator, Mr. Laxmi, and the opportunity to learn about local traditions through engaging commentary. It is considered a worthwhile, affordable, and culturally enriching visit that feels like a genuine connection to the area's heritage.

Today we visited the Thar Heritage Museum and it was a truly enriching experience. Though the museum is small in size, it houses a unique and fascinating collection showcasing the traditional lifestyle, culture, and even astrology of Rajasthan.

The artifacts are well-preserved, and the entire place is beautifully maintained. What made the visit even more special was the interaction with Mr. Khatri, the owner, who shared valuable insights and stories behind the exhibits.

Surprisingly, many antique items and souvenirs were available at very reasonable prices. Overall, it’s a hidden gem in Jaisalmer that reflects the soul of the desert in the most authentic way. Highly recommended for anyone who loves history, culture, and heritage!

Really worth Visiting!

Nestled in the heart of Jaisalmer, just 2 km from the iconic Jaisalmer Fort, **Mandir Palace**, also known as **Badal Vilas**, offers a fascinating blend of history, heritage, and hospitality. This magnificent palace, still partially serving as the residence of the royal family, transports visitors to a bygone era of Rajput grandeur.

Architectural Charm & Heritage
The exterior of Mandir Palace is a striking example of traditional **Rajputana architecture**, featuring ornately carved facades, jharokhas, and intricately designed archways. Its golden sandstone structure glows in the sunlight, making it a favorite for photography and heritage enthusiasts alike.

Inside, parts of the palace function as a **museum**, displaying a modest collection of royal artifacts, weapons, and historical relics. While not extensive, it provides a brief insight into Jaisalmer’s royal lineage.

**rooftop view**—offering stunning panoramas of the **Jaisalmer Fort**, the Golden City, and the **Thar Desert**, especially at sunrise and sunset.

Visiting Experience & Entry Fees
Museum comes at a fee of approximately **₹160–₹250**, with an additional **₹30** for mobile photography. While the architecture is beautiful, the **museum section is relatively small**, and some might find it underwhelming if expecting a large exhibit.

Overall Impression
Mandir Palace / Badal Vilas is not just a structure—it's a **living piece of Jaisalmer's royal legacy**. While the museum might not justify the ticket price for every visitor, the architectural beauty, tranquil atmosphere, and regal charm still make it a **worthwhile stop**, especially for those interested in heritage and history.

Mandir Palace, also known as Badal Mahal, is a beautiful blend of royal heritage and intricate Rajasthani architecture right in the heart of Jaisalmer. The finely carved jharokhas, peaceful atmosphere, and the tall Badal Vilas tower offer a majestic view of the Golden City. Though the museum section is small, the charm of the palace and its rooftop views make it worth a visit. Ideal for photography lovers and those who appreciate history, but day visitors should know access is limited. Still, it's a must-visit gem for a quick royal experience in Jaisalmer.

Mandir Palace, also known as Badal Vilas, offers a captivating blend of heritage and hospitality that immerses visitors in the rich history of Jaisalmer. Our stay at this majestic palace was a journey through time, where the walls echoed tales of a bygone era.

The architecture of Mandir Palace is a testament to the opulence of Rajputana design. Intricately carved facades, delicate jharokhas, and regal archways transport guests to an era of grandeur. The palace's seamless integration with its historical surroundings enhances its allure, creating an oasis of splendor in the heart of the Golden City.

Our accommodations at Badal Vilas were nothing short of regal. The rooms, adorned with traditional Rajasthani decor, provided a perfect blend of comfort and antiquity. The attention to detail in the furnishings and the preservation of the palace's historical elements added a touch of authenticity to our stay.

One of the highlights of our visit was the exquisite dining experience. The palace's restaurant served a delectable array of Rajasthani and international cuisines. The culinary journey was elevated by the elegant setting, and the attentive staff ensured a dining experience that matched the grandeur of the palace.

The palace staff deserves commendation for their impeccable service. From the warm welcome at the entrance to the prompt and courteous assistance throughout our stay, the hospitality at Mandir Palace exemplifies the legendary Rajput hospitality.

The rooftop views at Badal Vilas were nothing short of breathtaking. The panoramic vistas of Jaisalmer Fort, the cityscape, and the vast Thar Desert painted a mesmerizing picture, especially during sunrise and sunset. These moments created memories that will linger long after our stay.

While Mandir Palace offers an enchanting experience, it's important to note that, like many historical establishments, there may be occasional maintenance challenges. However, the staff's quick response to address any concerns demonstrated their commitment to ensuring a comfortable stay for guests.

In conclusion, Mandir Palace, or Badal Vilas, is more than a hotel; it's a journey into the grandeur of Jaisalmer's history. The palace's architectural splendor, luxurious accommodations, delectable cuisine, and warm hospitality make it a destination that transcends the ordinary. Our stay at Mandir Palace was not just a visit; it was an immersive experience in the regal charm of Rajasthan's heritage.

I had a very disappointing experience visiting this place. The entry fee is ₹160 per person, which is quite high considering what’s actually accessible. Most of the doors are locked, and you’re not allowed to see the interior of many areas that are supposedly part of the tour.

What made things worse was the rude and unprofessional behavior of the watchmen and staff. They were not helpful at all, and treated visitors with disrespect, which is completely unacceptable—especially at a historical or tourist site.

This place clearly survives on its name and heritage but doesn’t respect tourists or provide value for the money charged. Locals are not allowing to take photos from outside,I wouldn’t recommend it to anyone unless there are major improvements in how visitors are treated and what access is allowed.

reviews.reviewText:
This was an absolutely brilliant puppet show and a very good price - 200 rupees for the puppet show and entry to the museum (for an international adult visitor, cheaper for locals and children). The puppets were beautiful and the music and puppetry were amazing to experience and very skilful. We loved the commentary as well which was amusing and very helpful to understand the show. We were also lucky enough to meet the founder of the museum who was lovely. It was also possible to buy puppets there for a very reasonable cost.
We were mainly going for the puppet show but the museum had some interesting
artifacts and we spent about 30 minutes there. There is also a lovely rooftop restaurant with a great view of Jaisalmer fort.

> Entry fee is Rs. 200 (For Museum & Puppet Show)
> Show timing is 6.30 PM to 7.30 PM & 7.30 PM to 8.30 PM
> Located opposite Gadisar Lake.
> The puppet show is worth seeing.

I felt just amazing, its my first puppet show. And during this show when musician share some history facts through story form, its just  wow , must visit beautiful place you will experience not just show + bookshop+ museum.

They literally did the show just for four of us (family). That gesture itself is enough to understand how much they value the footfall.
Because of other popular tourist places in city like Jaisalmer, this goes as an unnoticed place to visit. However, after our experience at the puppet show and looking at the humbleness of artists, I must say this should be the point no 1 place to visit (it is very close to Gadisar lake). One, this kind of shows are dying in India and now few traces left here & there or in movies, or in text books or on YouTube. Two, artists feel so much empowered even for few claps that itself is a great experience. I recommend this culture museum and the puppet show to everyone who visit the Jaisalmer city. Take kids with you if you are with family as they need to see these shows, who knows when will these fade away.
I would like to mention few names:
Mr Hemant Sharma who runs this museum and maintained it very well. The museum also offers some great art and things to shop.
Next the artists group led by Mr Imamdin along with Rahul & Kalyan Bhat, they are great human beings & artists. Huge thanks to them for entertaining us whole heartedly. ❤️

Very interesting museum with amazing guide Hemant ! He explained a lot of very interesting facts about the city and the region in amazing english and even performed a local song. Would greatly recommand !
Very interesting museum with an energetic and passionate guide! Learned so much about the local culture and history. Highly recommend if you’re visiting Jaisalmer

The puppet show is really amazing. The artists are incredible. Singing, puppet dancing , musical instruments are  awesome.
They have two shows every evening. 6:30 and 7:30 p.m.  charges only 200 per person with camera and including museum too.

I'm absolutely thrilled to have experienced my first puppet show, and it exceeded my expectations in every way! What made it truly special was the musician's ability to weave history facts into the story, making it both entertaining and educational. The venue itself is a treasure trove - a beautiful place that offers a unique blend of art, culture, and learning. The puppet show, bookshop, and museum all come together to create an immersive experience that's hard to find elsewhere.
What really made the experience feel like home was the warm and welcoming nature of the staff, particularly the uncle and dadi ji who engaged with us in a way that felt like a conversation with family. Their passion and enthusiasm were infectious, and it added a personal touch to the entire experience.
I would highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a unique and enriching experience. The blend of art, history, and culture is truly special, and the warm hospitality makes it feel like a home away from home. Thank you for creating such a wonderful experience!
Thank you 💙..!!

sources.snippet: -This time it’s time to celebrate your life in the desert with this exciting half-day desert safari in Jaisalmer.-You will depart at around 4:30 PM from your hotel pick up service in a sedan car and then will return after sunset at around 10:30 PM on the same day.-Reach the Sam desert at around 5:00 PM, which is just 45 minutes drive from Jaisalmer.-Embark on the short camel ride and explore the beautiful dunes of Sam desert.-After the camel ride, witness one of the most beautiful sunsets behind the dunes and head to the camp.-Get a traditional welcome with arti-tikka and dhols and enjoy the refreshments like tea, coffee and snacks while you enjoy the Rajasthani folk dance and music. show-Groove to the music and enjoy a delicious authentic Rajasthani veg buffet dinner.-End your trip at around 10:30 PM and get yourself Dropped at your hotel with lots of memories. Timings: 4:30 PM - 10: 30 PMMinimum number of people required: 1

Overall, our desert safari experience with Desert Safari Planners was truly exceptional. We enjoyed every moment of our stay, and we would highly recommend this company to anyone looking for a memorable and adventurous desert safari experience.

placeMetadata.description: Collection of objects with historical, artistic & cultural significance to the area.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Folklore Museum in Jaisalmer, located within the Jaisalmer Fort, offers a captivating journey through the heritage of Rajasthan. Founded by Dr. Nand Kishore Sharma in 1997, this museum is a treasure trove of artifacts showcasing traditional costumes, musical instruments, artworks, ancient coins, fossils, and more. Visitors can immerse themselves in the customs and traditions that define the state while enjoying an evening puppet show - a major attraction at this small yet intriguing museum.
placeMetadata.address: WW5C+P4H, Postal Colony, Jaisalmer, Rajasthan 345001, India

reviews.reviewText:
Finally a museum that shares the story of who and why Rajasthan was founded in the very beginning.

The museum charges nothing extra to foreigners or Indians alike but the man who owns/maintains the facility has no support from the government. As a result the displays are dated and require a lot of reading.

This is not a "ooo look! A buddha statue! Let me take a quick selfie and move on!" kind of museum. Every peice has full descriptions to its importance in Hindi and English.

I cannot say how refreshing it was to go here after so many religious museums in this part of the world.

Introduction of Jaisalmer Folklore Museum

Jaisalmer Folklore Museum is situated on the banks of Garsisar Lake in the Mehar Bagh Garden, this museum was founded in the year 1984. There is a wide variety of artifacts inside the museum which offers a great experience to the visitors. Visitors will get a detailed idea about the various significant historical events on visiting the museum.

This place is by far the worst spot I visited while in Rajasthan. One would think taking 100rs as entry fee would come with some maintenance of this place.. but no, as you can see in my photos, this place is an absolute dump, trash and rubble everywhere. Not worth anyone's time.

Salim Singh Ki Haveli is a must-visit in Jaisalmer! The architecture is truly unique — the peacock-shaped roof and the beautifully carved balconies are breathtaking. The haveli’s design stands out with its creative structure and intricate detailing. You can feel the rich history in every corner, and the guides provide interesting stories and insights about Salim Singh and the legacy of this place. The view from the top is stunning, offering a great perspective of the golden city. Highly recommend visiting this historical gem

Avoid This Place – Save Yourself from a Bad Experience
Jaisalmer is full of beauty and history, but visiting Salim Singh’s Haveli might be the only negative experience you have here.

Why would you even want to visit? The haveli is supposedly famous for its unique architecture—no cement construction—but now, there's visible cement work, ruining its original charm. In reality, it feels more like ruins than a heritage site. Just look at the pictures.

If you're feeling charitable, take the ticket and admire it from the outside. But do not go in, or you risk encountering the exceptionally rude guide. A review from two years ago already mentioned his attitude and unfortunately, nothing has changed—neither his behavior nor the neglected state of the place. Clearly, the owner isn't bothered.

Skipping this place isn’t about saving the ₹100 (also 20 for taking pictures) entry fee. It’s about keeping your Jaisalmer memories positive. Do yourself a favor and visit other, better-preserved sites instead.

Jaisalmer Fort is truly a unique experience! The architecture is stunning and full of intricate details that make you appreciate the craftsmanship of the past. What makes it even more special is that it’s not just a fort – it’s like a living village inside. You’ll find homes, shops, and small streets that give it a lively and authentic feel. Walking through it feels like stepping back in time. Definitely a must-visit in Jaisalmer!

Jaisalmer Fort is not just a monument, it’s a living, breathing heritage site. Unlike most forts in India, people still reside inside, making it feel like a golden city within a fort. The yellow sandstone walls glow beautifully at sunrise and sunset, giving it the name “Sonar Quila” (Golden Fort).

Inside, you’ll find narrow lanes full of vibrant shops, handicrafts, rooftop cafes with stunning views, ancient Jain temples, and historic havelis. Exploring it feels like stepping back in time.

✔️ Must-do:

Visit during sunset for breathtaking golden hues.

Explore Jain Temples (intricate carvings).

Walk through the local markets for souvenirs.

Try a rooftop café for city views.

⚠️ Tips:

Wear comfortable footwear (lots of walking on stone paths).

Hire a local guide to know the hidden stories.

Early morning or evening visits are best to avoid heat.

Overall, Jaisalmer Fort is a unique experience – a UNESCO World Heritage site where history, culture, and daily life blend seamlessly. A must-visit if you’re in Rajasthan!

Sonar Kila, also known as Jaisalmer Fort, is one of the most magnificent forts in India and a true architectural wonder. Built with yellow sandstone, the fort glows like gold under sunlight, which is why it’s called “Sonar Kila”. Its massive walls, intricate carvings, and royal gateways reflect the rich heritage and craftsmanship of Rajasthan.

During my Jaisalmer visit, unfortunately, I couldn’t explore the fort from the inside due to time limitations, but I managed to capture some beautiful night-time photos from outside. The fort looks even more mesmerizing at night when it’s beautifully lit, creating a magical view.

Next time, I definitely plan to explore the fort from inside, as it’s home to historic palaces, Jain temples, and vibrant markets. Even if you can’t go inside, I highly recommend visiting Sonar Kila at least once to witness its majestic beauty from the outside — it’s truly unforgettable!

Architecturally notable residence built in 1815 with a peacock-shaped roof & numerous balconies.
Massive, 12th-century fortified city featuring ornate Jain temples with idols & stone carvings.
Warm dorms & private rooms in a laid-back hostel offering a rooftop cafe, a TV lounge & free Wi-Fi.
Collection of objects with historical, artistic & cultural significance to the area.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we’re always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Jaisalmer, often referred to as the 'Golden City', is a mesmerizing blend of history, culture, and stunning landscapes that beckons photographers and travelers alike. Nestled amidst the golden sands of the Thar Desert, this enchanting city is home to the magnificent Jaisalmer Fort, a UNESCO World Heritage site that stands as a testament to the region's rich heritage. With its intricate Jain temples and vibrant local life, the fort offers countless opportunities for capturing the essence of this unique destination. As the sun sets, the warm hues of the desert create a magical backdrop, making it a photographer's paradise.

Beyond the fort, Jaisalmer is dotted with picturesque spots that showcase its natural beauty and architectural wonders. From the serene waters of Gadisar Lake, where migratory birds flock at sunrise, to the intricately carved Patwon Ki Haveli, each location tells a story waiting to be captured. Whether you're wandering through the vibrant streets or exploring the tranquil sand dunes at Sam, Jaisalmer offers a plethora of stunning vistas that will inspire your creativity. So grab your camera and get ready to explore the best photo spots this captivating city has to offer!
